name: Copy
description: The Copy SOP lets you make copies of the geometry of other SOPs and apply a transformation to each copy.
summary: The Copy SOP lets you make copies of the geometry of other SOPs and apply a transformation to each copy.

parameters.name: Source Group
parameters.label: Source Group
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
The Copy  lets you make copies of the geometry of other SOPs and apply a transformation to each copy.		
It also allows you to copy geometry to points on an input template.
copySOP_Class

Contents
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 





Specifies a subset of template primitives from which to copy onto. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching.

  sourcegrp - Specifies a subset of input primitives to copy from. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching.



  templategrp - Specifies a subset of template primitives from which to copy onto. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching.



  ncy - Sets number of Copies to be made of the source. For a template input, it specifies the number of copies to be placed at each point of the template.



  nprims - Defines how many primitives to copy from each point.



  nml - Only used when a template input is specified. If the template is a sphere, and the first input is a circle, a circle is placed at each point of the sphere. With this option on, all the circles will re-orient to face the surface of the sphere (a default sphere has normals radiating outwards from the center).	
If an up attribute exists on the template geometry, then this will be used (along with the normal) to fully define the rotates for the copies. An up attribute is created with the  .



  cum - Each transformation "builds" on the location left by the one before it. Transformations are cumulative as the Copy  produces new copies.



  xord -  - Sets the overall transform order for the transformations. The  determines the order in which transformations take place. Depending on the order, you can achieve different results using the exact same values. Choose the appropriate order from the menu.

 srt - str - rst - rts - tsr - trs -

  rord -  - Sets the order of the rotations within the overall transform order.

 xyz - xzy - yxz - yzx - zxy - zyx -

  t -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

 tx - ty - tz -

  r -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

 rx - ry - rz -

  s -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

 sx - sy - sz -

  p -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

 px - py - pz -

  scale - Uniform Scale allows you to shrink or enlarge geometry along all three axes simultaneously.



  vlength - Vector type attributes (i.e. normals, velocity) maintain the same length under transforms. i.e. When geometry is scaled, the normals remain constant in length.



  newg - If selected, this creates a group for each copy number, and places each primitive created at that stage into it.



  copyg - Defines the base name of the groups created.



  lookat - Orients the copied geometry to lookat, or point to, the object component specified in the parameter.



  upvector -  - When specifying a Look At, it is possible to specify an up vector for the lookat. Without using an up vector, it is possible to get poor animation when the lookat object passes through the Y axis of the target object.

 upvectorx - upvectory - upvectorz -



Stamping is allowed in any parameter in TouchDesigner. The only requirement is that the stamped parameter is upstream in some fashion from the Copy  doing the stamping.

  stamp - When enabled, it will Stamp proceeding variables for each input copied.



  copy - Sequence of stamp variables



  copy0param - Token of each stamp variable. Stamped parameters are accessible via the global  method in the td Module in python, or param() in tscript. See the example, below.



  copy0value - Value of each stamp variable. Stamped parameters are accessible via the global  method in the td Module in python, or param() in tscript. See the example, below.






This page allows you to determine how point attributes on template geometry affect attributes on the source geometry. The template attribute can modify the source in four ways:		

Set - Override the source attribute.
Multiply - Multiply the source attribute.
Add - Get Added to the source attribute.
Sub - Get Subtracted from the source attribute.The template point attributes are able to affect point, primitive, or vertex attributes in the source geometry simply by entering values in the appropriate fields.

  doattr - Enables the parameters below to allow template point attributes to be applied to the copied source geometry.



  setpt -  - Copy the attributes to the source geometry's points.

 * -

  setprim -  - Copy the attributes to the source geometry's primitives.

 * -

  setvtx -  - Copy the attributes to the source geometry's vertices.

 * -

  mulpt -  - Multiply the attributes with the source geometry's point attributes.

 * -

  mulprim -  - Multiply the attributes with the source geometry's primitive attributes.

 * -

  mulvtx -  - Multiply the attributes with the source geometry's vertex attributes.

 * -

  addpt -  - Add the attributes to the source geometry's point attributes.

 * -

  addprim -  - Add the attributes to the source geometry's primitive attributes.

 * -

  addvtx -  - Add the attributes to the source geometry's vertex attributes.

 * -

  subpt -  - Subtract the attributes from the source geometry's point attributes.

 * -

  subprim -  - Subtract the attributes from the source geometry's primitive attributes.

 * -

  subvtx -  - Subtract the attributes from the source geometry's vertex attributes.

 * -



You can use the me.copyTotal python member to calculate the degrees of rotation for a given number of copies. For example, if you have 28 copies, you can set the rotation to be: 360/me.copyTotal - this would automatically give you 12.8571 degrees, evenly spacing your 28 copies around the full circumference of the circle.
Using a Particle  as the Template object, you can copy objects defined in the Copy Data input to each particle template. This allows you, for example, to copy a Bee to each particle to create a swarm of bees.
Make a series of copies about an axis, and skin them to achieve lathe-like effects, similar to the results achieved with the Revolve .



Place a Circle , and set its type to .
Set the number of Divisions in the Circle to:  The method  returns the value of the global parameter sides. If it is not yet defined it will return a value of 3.
Append a Copy , and set the Number of Copies to 5; and set Translate X to: 2.5 .
In the Stamp page of the Copy , turn on Stamp Inputs. Set Param 1 to: sides and 
This creates a triangle on the first stamped copy; a square on the next; a pentagon on the third, and so on. The geometry for each copy is cooked separately.
You can set multiple stamp Params at once and they can be used anywhere in the ancestry of the copy's input.


 -
 -

Extra Information for the Copy  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.



 - Number of points in this . - Number of primitives in this . - Number of particles in this . - Time spent in another thread updating geometry data on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time. - Time spent in another thread updating meta surface geometry data (such as metaballs or nurbs) on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
TouchDesigner Build: Latest\nwikieditorwikieditorwikieditorwikieditor2022.241402021.100002020.200002018.28070before 2018.28070
SOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



Each SOP has a list of Points. Each point has an XYZ 3D position value plus other optional attributes. Each polygon Primitive is defined by a vertex list, which is list of point numbers.



Information associated with SOP geometry. Points and primitives (polygons, NURBS, etc.) can have any number of attributes - position (P) is standard, and built-in optional attributes are normals (N), texture coordinates (uv), color (Cd), etc.



A surface type in SOPs that includes polygon, curve (NURBS and Bezier), patch (NURBS and Bezier) and other basic shapes like sphere, tube and metaball. Points and Primitives are part of the Geometry Detail, which is a part of a SOP.



A sequence of vertices form a Polygon in a SOP. Each vertex is an integer index into the Point List, and each Point holds an XYZ position and attributes like Normals and Texture Coordinates.



The 3D data held in SOPs and passed for rendering by the Geometry COMP.



A polygon is a type of Primitive that is formed from a set of Vertices in 3D that are implicitly connected together to form a multi-edge shape.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



The Graphics Processing Unit. This is the high-speed, many-core processor of the graphics card/chip that takes geometry, images and data from the CPU and creates images and processed data.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Copy_SOP&oldid=32298"
		Category: SOPs

 - Number of points in this . - Number of primitives in this . - Number of particles in this . - Time spent in another thread updating geometry data on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time. - Time spent in another thread updating meta surface geometry data (such as metaballs or nurbs) on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
TouchDesigner Build: Latest\nwikieditorwikieditorwikieditorwikieditor2022.241402021.100002020.200002018.28070before 2018.28070
SOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



Each SOP has a list of Points. Each point has an XYZ 3D position value plus other optional attributes. Each polygon Primitive is defined by a vertex list, which is list of point numbers.



Information associated with SOP geometry. Points and primitives (polygons, NURBS, etc.) can have any number of attributes - position (P) is standard, and built-in optional attributes are normals (N), texture coordinates (uv), color (Cd), etc.



A surface type in SOPs that includes polygon, curve (NURBS and Bezier), patch (NURBS and Bezier) and other basic shapes like sphere, tube and metaball. Points and Primitives are part of the Geometry Detail, which is a part of a SOP.



A sequence of vertices form a Polygon in a SOP. Each vertex is an integer index into the Point List, and each Point holds an XYZ position and attributes like Normals and Texture Coordinates.



The 3D data held in SOPs and passed for rendering by the Geometry COMP.



A polygon is a type of Primitive that is formed from a set of Vertices in 3D that are implicitly connected together to form a multi-edge shape.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



The Graphics Processing Unit. This is the high-speed, many-core processor of the graphics card/chip that takes geometry, images and data from the CPU and creates images and processed data.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Copy_SOP&oldid=32298"

parameters.name: Source Group
parameters.label: Source Group
parameters.description: sourcegrp - Specifies a subset of input primitives to copy from. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching.

parameters.name: Template Group
parameters.label: Template Group
parameters.description: templategrp - Specifies a subset of template primitives from which to copy onto. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching.

parameters.name: Number of Copies
parameters.label: Number of Copies
parameters.description: ncy - Sets number of Copies to be made of the source. For a template input, it specifies the number of copies to be placed at each point of the template.

parameters.name: Primitives per Point
parameters.label: Primitives per Point
parameters.description: nprims - Defines how many primitives to copy from each point.

parameters.name: Rotate to Normal
parameters.label: Rotate to Normal
parameters.description:
nml - Only used when a template input is specified. If the template is a sphere, and the first input is a circle, a circle is placed at each point of the sphere. With this option on, all the circles will re-orient to face the surface of the sphere (a default sphere has normals radiating outwards from the center).	
If an up attribute exists on the template geometry, then this will be used (along with the normal) to fully define the rotates for the copies. An up attribute is created with the  .

parameters.name: Transform Cumulative
parameters.label: Transform Cumulative
parameters.description: cum - Each transformation "builds" on the location left by the one before it. Transformations are cumulative as the Copy  produces new copies.

parameters.name: Transform Order
parameters.label: Transform Order
parameters.description:
xord -  - Sets the overall transform order for the transformations. The  determines the order in which transformations take place. Depending on the order, you can achieve different results using the exact same values. Choose the appropriate order from the menu.

 srt - str - rst - rts - tsr - trs -

parameters.name: Scale Rotate Translate
parameters.label: Scale Rotate Translate
parameters.description: srt - str - rst - rts - tsr - trs -

parameters.name: Rotate Order
parameters.label: Rotate Order
parameters.description:
rord -  - Sets the order of the rotations within the overall transform order.

 xyz - xzy - yxz - yzx - zxy - zyx -

parameters.name: Rx Ry Rz
parameters.label: Rx Ry Rz
parameters.description: xyz - xzy - yxz - yzx - zxy - zyx -

parameters.name: Translate
parameters.label: Translate
parameters.description:
t -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

 tx - ty - tz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: tx - ty - tz -

parameters.name: Rotate
parameters.label: Rotate
parameters.description:
r -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

 rx - ry - rz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: rx - ry - rz -

parameters.name: Scale
parameters.label: Scale
parameters.description:
s -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

 sx - sy - sz -

parameters.name: Pivot
parameters.label: Pivot
parameters.description:
p -  - These allow you to specify the Translation (how much it moves over in a given direction), Rotation, and the Scale between each copy. Three columns are given for X, Y, and Z coordinates. Guide geometry is provided for the Pivot's translations. The Pivot is represented by a single red dot in the Viewport. Changing the Pivot parameters moves this point of reference.

parameters.name: X

parameters.name: Uniform Scale
parameters.label: Uniform Scale
parameters.description: scale - Uniform Scale allows you to shrink or enlarge geometry along all three axes simultaneously.

parameters.name: Normals Maintain Length
parameters.label: Normals Maintain Length
parameters.description: vlength - Vector type attributes (i.e. normals, velocity) maintain the same length under transforms. i.e. When geometry is scaled, the normals remain constant in length.

parameters.name: Create Output Groups
parameters.label: Create Output Groups
parameters.description: newg - If selected, this creates a group for each copy number, and places each primitive created at that stage into it.

parameters.name: Copy Groups
parameters.label: Copy Groups
parameters.description: copyg - Defines the base name of the groups created.

parameters.name: Look At
parameters.label: Look At
parameters.description: lookat - Orients the copied geometry to lookat, or point to, the object component specified in the parameter.

parameters.name: Up Vector
parameters.label: Up Vector
parameters.description:
upvector -  - When specifying a Look At, it is possible to specify an up vector for the lookat. Without using an up vector, it is possible to get poor animation when the lookat object passes through the Y axis of the target object.

 upvectorx - upvectory - upvectorz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: upvectorx - upvectory - upvectorz -

parameters.name: Stamp Inputs
parameters.label: Stamp Inputs
parameters.description: stamp - When enabled, it will Stamp proceeding variables for each input copied.

parameters.name: Copy
parameters.label: Copy
parameters.description:
copy - Sequence of stamp variables



  copy0param - Token of each stamp variable. Stamped parameters are accessible via the global  method in the td Module in python, or param() in tscript. See the example, below.



  copy0value - Value of each stamp variable. Stamped parameters are accessible via the global  method in the td Module in python, or param() in tscript. See the example, below.

parameters.name: Param
parameters.label: Param
parameters.description: copy0param - Token of each stamp variable. Stamped parameters are accessible via the global  method in the td Module in python, or param() in tscript. See the example, below.

parameters.name: Value
parameters.label: Value
parameters.description: copy0value - Value of each stamp variable. Stamped parameters are accessible via the global  method in the td Module in python, or param() in tscript. See the example, below.

parameters.name: Use Template Point Attribs
parameters.label: Use Template Point Attribs
parameters.description: doattr - Enables the parameters below to allow template point attributes to be applied to the copied source geometry.

parameters.label: Copy to Point
parameters.description:
setpt -  - Copy the attributes to the source geometry's points.

 * -

 * -

parameters.label: Multiply Point
parameters.description:

parameters.label: Subtract Primitive

subprim -  - Subtract the attributes from the source geometry's primitive attributes.
